div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of “Othello'' and of Ford's “Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

THE GREATEST care should be taken in what we eat and drink, yet we are too often indifferent and careless, notwithstanding health depends on what we eat and drink.

In regard to drink nothing but the best should be taken. It costs no more than the indifferent quality, if people would only ask for what they know is the best Old Scotch Whisky is the most wholesome beverage yet known Mackie's Scotch Whisky gives an undoubted guarantee to those who are not judges of quality.
CITY ANALYSTS LABORATORY,
138 BATH STREET,
GLASC0W, 8th October, 1906.

I hereby certify that I have taken samples of every vatting of Mackie's White Horse Celler Blend of Scotch Whisky used in bottling during the month of September, and the results of my analyses indicate that it conforms to the standard for Pot Still Scotch Whisky set up in the London case. I am also of opinion that it is an old Whisky of excellent quality and flavour, which has been well matured in wood.
JOHN CLARK, Ph.D., F.C.S., F.I.C.,

p.hi: Public Analyst for the City of Glasgow and the Counties of Lanark, Renfrew, &c.

div.p: N.B.—This Whisky is the same as supplied to the Red Cross Society, London, to the House of Lords and House of Commons.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARCHEOLOGY
div.p: Writing in the "Globe" on "Prehistoric Arts and Crafts", W. St. Chad Boscawen says:-"Of all the nations of antiquity, Egypt alone presents us with a continuous panorama of records, covering not only the historic ages, but also extending far back into the dim misty, prehistoric times. The material gathered from the graves in the great predynastic cemeteriés at Abydos, Nagada, and Geblen reveal to us the life of ages far beyond those of any other Oriental people. It is but a moderate estimate to place the neolithic age, to which the best work of these people must be assigned, at a period of some seven thousand years before the Christian era. How much further back must we go for the more primitive work, and to what still more remote period must we assign the remains of paleolithic man. The first discovery of this prehistoric race in the Nile Valley is due to Professor Petrie, but he failed at-first to recognise their position, regarding them as a new, or foreign, people who had forced their way into the Nile Valley in early dynastic times, and it was really M. de Morgan who first recognised in them the pre-dynastic population of Egypt. The harvest of antiquities which have been gathered from the graves of this most ancient people is, indeed, most prolific, and the story to be reconstructed from their evidence most important. The collections of the British Museum, Oxford, Liverpool, as well as the Edwards Museum in University-College, Lon- don, all contain valuable objects, and there are several large private collections. Having had the opportunity of examinining thoroughly - one of the latter, I have been able to ascertain several interesting points as to the dawn of the arts and crafts in the Nile Valley. The prehistoric Egyptians, like those of later times, buried their dead with some hope of a future life, and so placed in the tombs the objects they most needed in life on earth. In the prehistoric grave exhibited in the British Museum, this mode may be seen. The dead man lies in the attitude of sleep, and around him are earthen pots and flint weapons. The of the various examples we are able to establish & regular sequence in the development of the various forms.

“As I have stated elsewhere, man learned the art of making pottery. fromi the bird’s nest. The nest showed him how to make baskets, and the claylined nest suggested the clay-lined basket. The heating of one of these basket pots produced a baked clay dish or pot, the sides of Which were marked with a basket-” work pattern. Man soon learned to maxe these pots and bake them, but retained the old basket pattern as a decoration. These pots grew larger, assuming an urn and often had knobs or lungs on the side to hold a cord, for suspension. In course ot time the upper part was curved in; making shoulders to the jar and giving the jar an ovoid shape This was no doubt done to regulate the out-pouring of fluids, a rim was added, and this in due course became higher, and formed a neck.

“The ware is usually red or yellowish buff, and decorated with a black band at the top. This has heen generally considered to be due to the action of heat in the ashes- of the kiln, the vases being placed nozzle down, but several of the examples I examined showed traces of the black glaze having run, as if puton in a liquid form. In the same way, it would other- wise be difficult to explain the method by which the insides were glazed black, The most important and difficult problem to solve was the method by which these vessels were made and so beautifully finished—the potter's wheel not having been invented. I think that I am able to suggest a solution: Among the exam- ples I examined were several unfinished specimens. In some of these, the outsides were well baked, the usual black band round the top was there, and the outer surface polished with the polishing stone» The inside, however, revealed some interesting.material. They were unfinished, and rough, badly-baked jumps of clay adhered to the sides. A still further examination showed clearly the marks of, flint scrapers that had been used to hollow lout the interior The method of manufacture’ now appears clear. The vase was made solid, then partially dried, and the interior carefully. scraped out with flint scrapers, and after- wards the vase was baked. This seems to be confirmed by’a statue in the Cairo Museum, which shows a man thus working the interior. It must finally be. noted that this was undoubt- edly the method in which,the alabaster vases were made in later times. Another valuable find I must also mention, The vases in the Maseam are decorated with drawings of Nile boats, men, ostriches, and animals, but hitherto no regular pictorial story has been found. One vase in this collection, however, . has more sequence in its decoration than any I have seen before. It is a large yellow buff vase about twelve inches high. The bottom part has a wave pattern decoration in red. On the main body an interesting scene is depicted. In the upper part two prehistoric Nile boats are represented, evidently méored to the bank. There are cabins on deck, on the roof of which little ten in an attitude denoting excitement or activity are standing.) At the head .of each boat a taller man stands, thé.attitude of his arms denoting the giving of orders. On the bank between the - two boatd:is ¥, ill, taller man, whose arms are ~ spread out-as if giving the supreme orders. Here then. we have clearly the picture of a Nilé boat expedition landing on the bank of the river. Below this group is represented a number. of huts, in one of which a dead body is clearly: shown. This is evidently the village raided.

“The lower tier is very interesting. On the left isa man with a long staff in his hand, who is advancing towards a grove of palm trees. Behind him is a giraffe, round whose neck he had a lasso. Before him ran two dogs. On the right is another group, a Barbary ram and two kids. The ram stands in front of them, and raises his foot in an angry manner, to ward off the approaching dogs. The whole is most crudely drawn, but: it’ nevertheless tella its story with much force and detail, Here, then, we see how much we learn of the dawn of the arts in Egypt some eight or nine thousand years ago. ”

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Omar Pasha Toussoun left for Cairo this morning.
We regret to announce the death, which took place yesterday in Cairo, of Ali Pasha Fahmi, the well-known native engineer, who was a brother-in-law of Prince Haider Pasha.
Sir Reginald Wingate Pasha arrived in Cairo yesterday from Khartouth.
Lady Cromer will not be "at home" next Saturday afternoon.
Hussein Bey Rushdi, the newly appointed director-general of the Wakfs Administration, assumed his post yesterday.
Miralai Stanton Bey,Governér of Khartoum province, and Kaimakam Stott Hill Bey, senior assistant director of steamers and boats, have been granted three months leave of absence.
Kaimakam G. F. Clayton Bey has been transferred from the Sudan Government the Egyptian Army.
Mr. A.W. Hazel, inspector of the Ministry of the Interior, has been granted three months leave of absence dating from yesterday.
Me. J.F.G. Hopkins, inspector of the Ministry of the. Interior, will goon leave on June 4 and return to Egypt about the middle of September.
Bimbashi H.C, Potter,department of works, Sudan Government, has been granted the temporary rank of Kaimakam.

div.head: JUDICIAL ADVISORS REPORT
JUDICIAL STATISTICS
div.p: Sir Malcolm McIlwraith’s Report for the year 1906, which has just been published as a supplement to the “Journal Officiel,” is as thorough, concise, and lucid as ever, giving those interested in the administration of justice in this country an excellent grasp of the work which the Ministry of Justice is doing, and the manner in which that work is performed. The native tribunals are, of course, the first to receive the Judicial Adviser's attention and these are dealt with under five headings (1) judicial statistics,(2) civil jurisdiction, (3) eriminal jurisdiction, (4) committee of Surveil- lance, and (5) revision of the codes.

Up to the beginning of 1906 the collection of judicial statistics relating to the native tribunals was in the hands of the Procureur General and they were published as appendices to a special report issued by him. Now, how- ever, these are collected by the Ministry and are scheduled to the Report under review, In place of the civil statistics being scheduled in annual or weekly returns they are furnished to the Ministry in the form of monthly returns, and the data to be given are so arranged that the statistics over any given period can be obtained by the addition of the statisties for the separate months included in that period. This has proved especially useful in ascertain. ing the tribunals in which arrears tend to accumulate and in deciding where extra judicial Help is required. The criminal statistics are now centralised in a single office in the Ministry and are, as in the case of civil statistics, collected in monthly returns, This is, of course, of great importance to both the Ministry of Justice and that of the Interior, as providing an index to the criminality of the various parts of the country, and moreover it indicates the direction which inquiry should take in the event of it being desirable to criticise the exercise of his distretioh by a judge, member re Parquet, or police officer.

div.head: CIVIL JURISDICTION.
div.p: Civil jurisdiction is dealt with by Sir Malcolm McIlwraith under four headings, viz. markaz tribunals, summary tribunals, central tribunals and court of appeal. The difficulties connected with the extension of civil jurisdic- tion to markaz tribunals have not as yet been overcome, the chief of these being the accommodation of the necessary clerks and huissiers, and though numerous petitions have heen received from private persons for the extension of civil jurisdiction to certain mark- ages these have had to he shelved, and the riamber of those tribunal having civil juris- diction remains the sam as in 1905. The civil work im the summagy tribunals shows an increase of nearly 237 in the number of cases over 1905, an increase fairly well divided with the exception of Alexandria, where it is insignificant, The extension of the asiize court system to Upper Egypt hes proved a reonsiderable advantage to the sunimary tri- bunals and the result has been the dis of a largely increased number of cases, the figures being 138,107, an increase of nearly 23% over 1905, In the central tribunals those of first instance and those of Appeal are to be considered. Again in the central tribunals the extension of assize courts to Upper Egypt has enabled the Ministry to devote more time to civil work-in those tribunals and the number of first instance civil cases tried in 1906 (3,628) shows an increase of 447 over 1905 and 1147 over 1904, The increase is fairly general throughout the country, but is especially marked in Cairo and Beni Souef, the number of the cases at the latter tribunal being nearly doubled. The number of appeals for trial in 1906 were 4,151 as compared with 3, 414, in 1905. This increase of over 700 cases is entire- ly accounted for by the increase (over 20,000 cases) in the work of the summary courts, and had not the unappealable limit been raised the number of appeals would have been vastly greater. (To be continued)

div.head: EGYPT'S WATER SUPPLY
RAISING THE ASSOUAN DAM.
div.p: A dispatch from the Earl of Cromer respecting the water supply of Egypt was put before Parliament last week. It points out that the question of the best method of increasing the water supply has for some years been under consideration, and that various cases have contributed to delay a final decision on the subject. In the first place it seemed desirable especially in view of the important archio- logical interests involved, to study the differ ent sites for the construction of a dam. secdtid place; it was thought essential, before even entertaining a proposal to raise the Assouan Dam, to gain the experience of a few years, in order to watch the results obtained by the works already constructed. The engineer ing g problems involved in the question of how the dam should be raised also required very careful examination. Lord Cromer now appends to his despatch a note by Sir William Garstin, to which are attached further notes by Sir Benjamin Baker, Mr. Webb, and Captain Lyons. Sir William recommends that the Assouan Dam should be raised by seven metres, or approximately 28ft., at a cost of about LE. 1,500,000. The facts connected with the present situation, and the arguments which have led Sir William and others to their present conclusion, are fully stated in the documents accompanying the despatch.

div.head: PERENNIAL IRRIGATION.
div.p: In summarising the documents in question Lord Cromer observes that there can be no doubt of the enormous benefit which the Assouan reservoir has conferred. The actual direct gain to the Egyptian Treasury has been insignificant. The tidirect gain has been con- siderable, but it is diffigult to State precisely to what it amounts. The reason why the actual return to the Treasury has been small is that it was thought best to impose a very light land tax on the lands affected and thus leave the benefits derived from the reservolr to fructify in the pockets of the population. On the other hand the advantage to the country has been enormous. Sir William Garstin estimates that the sale value of the lands already provided with perennial irriga- tion has been increased by no less than LE 24,510,000, and that when the canals in course of constraction are completed this figure will be raised to no less than LE. 28,312,900. The increased rental value is already L.E. 1,465,000, and will eventually amount to L.E 2,022,359. The whole of this rise is directly attributable to the con- struction of the dam. In addition to this the cotton crop, the value of which was esti- mated last year at L.E. 28,000,000, has been secured. It is computed that the reservoir now supplies about a quatter of the water which will be eventually necessary for the needs of Egypt. If the dam is raised as Sir William Garstin proposes the water supply, after allowing a sufficient margin for evaporation, will be more than doubled. About 950.000 acres of land will be brought under cultivation. “The benefit to the country,” Sir William Garstin says, “will be immense.” The value of cotton crop in the area reclaimed will alone amount to from L.E. 3,500,000 to L.E. 4,000,000 a year. There can, therefore, Lord Cromer adds, “be no doubt as to the advisability of in- creasing the water supply.” Sir William Garstin points out that there are two methods of increasing the supply. One is to store the required amount of water in reservoirs cons- ructed in the Nile Valley. The other is to prevent the present waste of water in the vast Buhr-el-Gebel marshes, and thus increase the volume in the river passing Khartoum during the summer months. After a thorough examin- ation of the question Sir William and his coadjutors have arrived at the conclusion that “if Egypt is ever to be granted the volume required for perennial irrigation throughout its entire area, it will be necessary to make use of both methods for adding to the water supply.” All possible sites have been examined, and the opinion unanimously expressed by the engineers is that no alternative exists but that of raising the Assouan Dam.

div.head: ARCHEOLOGICAL CONSIDERATIONS.
div.p: Unfortunately that proposal involves the almost complete submersion, during a portion of the year, of the temples at Philae. Lord Cromer received a short time ago a letter from the Society of Antiquaries of London, in which they said: “The Society feel bound to enter a protest against any Scheme that would involve the wholesale destruction of archeological remains, unless it be clearly demonstrated that the scheme is an abso lute necessity for the well-being of Egypt and that the same benefits cannot be obtained in any other way.” Lord Cromer has no hesitation in saying that “ it would not be justifiable to sacrifice the pre- sent and future interests of the people Of Egypt in order to save the submersion of the tem- ples ”, Everything, however, will be done to mitigate the objections to the proposed scheme from an archeological point of view. The great engineering difficulties which the raisin. of the dam involve have been solved by Sir Benjamin Baker.

div.head: RELIEF FOR MATARIEH.
div.p: Over L.E. 1,000 have now been subscribed in the various towns of Egypt for the victims of the terrible Matarieh fire, and among the committees which have sent sums of money to the moudir of Dakahlieh has been that of the Orwa el Woska, whose subscription list exceeds £400.

div.head: TIMESAND
"LEWA" LORD CROMER'S WELL-WISHERS
div.p: “Will you walk into my parlour” said the spider to the fly, and this is almost exactly what the illustrious director of the various Standards is saying to the “Times” and its Cairo correspondent, who are desired to be more precise and to give not merely lists of offices, but names of those Egyptians who are said to have called at H.B.M.'s Agency (appalling accusation!) and to have expresses their regret at the resignation of Lord Cromer! How the tolerant chief of the Nationalist Party would love to obtain their names ; with whet fatherly gentleness he would point out to them the error of their ways, did that brutal and ill mannered organ. of Imperidlist im- posture described ad nauseam by Mr. Karamel, as an insignificant sheet, (though it contrives to be quoted at length about three times a week by the organs of the Stentor of the haria el Dawaween) only see fit to thank the ilustrious Karamel for his lengthy and gratuit- ous reclames by sending him a list neatly type- written for the benefit of myopic translators. True Karamel's recent utterances (in Arabic by the way) might inspire the Jando daily with the fear that the surrender of the names might lead to serions consequences ; that “spare the rod and spoil the child” might after all be the motto ofthe patriot leader and that the delinquents, not to put too fine a point on it, might endure revilings rather than re- proaches, the boycott rather than peaceful suasion, obloquy rather than good advice. Perhaps Karamel will be merciful.

Parcére subjectos et debellare superbos may after all be his watchword. Yet we have our doubts. Some days ago at the Catacloum in Cairo a French artist of merit and humour gave his audience a parody of the "Chant du Depart" of which we give some stanzas :—

L’air est pur, la coute est large Mustapha sonne la charge Et Lewa son Etendard Car il faut. que son eacorte Se figtire qu'il est en sorte L’Adteur du ‘Chant du Départ.” M'siew Férid qu'il tient on laisse Tape.sur la grosse calase Criant : Cost Tui quia fait ca Ils ont peur en Angleterre Je pense qu'il ferait mienx de se taire | Que de faire idiot comme cela. Certes tu trouverss des poires Qui eeront. dispostes & to, croire Mala tu rogrett'ras.ce départ ci Ti est vrai qu’ca Csera facile Car los larmes de Sont un produit du pays, Et maintenant qu'il te souvienne De la fable de la Fontaine Les grepouilles qui demandent un Roi Et Don Quichott’ de la Manque Avant d'faire le Naltimbanque . Tu regardran a deux fois, Obedient to the advice of Karamel to pay no heed to the criticisms of the enemies of the new evangel, to meet attacks with the calm and dignity worthy of the heirs of the Pharaonic and Islamic civilisations, some thirty of the friends of the prophet of tolerance attended a performance at the Catacloum and in the words of an onlooker “nearly smashed up the place.” Comment is needless : the conclusion that the names of Lord Cromer’s well wishers will not be given to Karamel and his friends appears to be well founded. The “Times” is not a fly—or it is too “fly”!

div.head: BRITISH RECREATION CLUB.
div.p: A most successful concert was held at the British Recreation Club, Cairo, on Saturday even- ing last, when a lengthy programme of sustain- ed excellence was Carried through before a large and appreciative audience of club members. A pianoforte sdlo by Mrs. Benani “Waltzinett,” Song “The Deathless Army’, Mr. Windsor, Gothic songs “I’m Billy Huggins” and “How date you” by Mr. W. Hill. Violin solos “Sonata” and “Coneert” by Mr. Borges; song “Angeline” Mr. Allen’; songs “I'm a Roanier’ and "Thou art passing hence," Mr. Mackintosh. Pianoforte duet “Un orage” Miss N. Hayes, and — L. Bain. Song “In Honour’s cause” Mr. Hayes. Duet “Hope,” Messrs. Hayes and Windsor, and musical interludes by Mr. Shirreff formed the principal items, and these were supplemented by numerous recalls. This concert will rank as one of the best held in the club during the season 1906-7 and the entertainment committee are fortunate in being able to secure the assistance of 80 many talented artists for the concerts held from time to time.

Where each in their separate spheres added so much to the pleasure of the assembled company, it may be somewhat unfair to make specific mention of any of the artistes, but the musical interludes by Mr. C W Shirreff proved quite interesting, varied and unique from a club point of view in the variety, and cleverness of the "form" introduced. His imitation of a prima donna and an Italian opera exhibited very considerable skill in this direction and his entertainment generally gave unalloyed satisfaction to all. Members generally trust that the smoking concert, to be given shortly, will be arranged with as little delay as possible and that the programme will, if possible, equal that submitted at last Saturday evening's concert.

div.head: SPORT IN SYRIA. FIELD DAY AT BEYROUT
(FROM OUR BEYROUT CORRESPONDENT)
div.p: The Annual Field Day of the Athletic Association of the Syrian Protestant College took place on Saturday April 20th, from 1.45 p.m The large well levelled lawn specially arranged for these athletic games and exercises is ad- mirably fitted for the purpose. From the special wooden stand improvised for the occasion for the College's distinguished visitors (I am told by the President that this stand is to be made next year permanent and of iron) the classic Mediterranean stretches northward at your feet while the not less classic Lebanon, more solemn still with its lingering snow shrouding its higher peaks rises majestically to the East; and one then remembers that these games took birth in this and neighboring lands skirt- ing this very Mediterranean. But how different these were in their object and their aim ! Athletic games with most of the ancients were afforded by highly specialized men, almost brought for a cruel public's amusement, whereas with us nowadays they have the much nobler aim of popularizing the principles of physical culture, and thus, while saving the race as a whole from physical degeneration, contribute to infuse into the individual the spirit of discipline and solidarity, and all that makes for the building of a strong and manly character. The following items of the programme serve to show the wide scope of physical culture in the College. 120 Yards Hurdles (Semi-final heat), Discus Throw, Running High Jump, 120 Yards Hurdles (Final Heat), Half Mile Run, Relay Race, Shot Put (16 pounds), 440 Yards Run, Jareed Throw, 100 Yards Dash (Final Heat) Mile Run, Championship Football Game, Collegiate v. Preparatory, besides the Physical Drill which deserves special mention. The organization of these games is made on pretty much the same lines as those of the great American Colleges. There are the usual officials viz. referee, judges, timers and assistant ushers. Then there are the officials flag and colours, the varsity flag represent- ing red cedar three on white field or vice versa, and its colors being red and white, while the five departments, medical pharma- ceutical, collegiate, commercial and prepara- tory, have each a special flag and special colors. Through the games this time there was a general falling off from the records, which was rather disappointing, until the last game, mile run, when the record of 5 min. 36 sec. was broken by 20 seconds, and a certain relief and satisfaction were felt by all those who look forward always to progress and advance. At the end of each game the winner is carried shoulder high and cheered by a crowd of students belonging to his department. The cry of the Collegiate department is of an amusingly savage character "Hurrah, Hurrah, Hurrah, Bumalaka, Bumalaka, Bum, Bum, Ba, Cheer for the College Ra, Ra, Ra"

It does ones own heart good to hear these wild cries thrown out by hundreds of lusty chests on that vast lawn that dominates the sea and the hills. The college counted last year about 600 students; this year the number has increased to 860. Lodging accomodation is now at its full and a dormitary is soon to be built to meet the anticipated increase in the present number of resident students. It has been possible for the college to promptly satisfy this need and start immediately the building of this annex, thanks to a very timely and munificent donation of 75,000 dollars made by the well-known American lady philanthropist Mrs. Russell Sage whose name will now be linked with this great monument of American missionary endeavour that will live forever in the annals of the near East. And this multitude of students is recruited from all parts of the near East with its strange mixture of creeds and races. There are Greeks from Greece proper, Turkey and the Isles, Armenians and Levantines, and a good percentage of Egyptians, but the majority is constituted by that rich variety of Syrians with their endless creeds ; and to lend this variety still stronger note there was this year amongst the competitors in various games a Moslem Indian. But all this heterogeneous mass is welded together into one cohesive solid bundle of young manhood, inspired with one spirit of the college and its ideals. And those games are one of the most powerful means that the college has for the attainment of this noble aim. Especially in the solidarity noticeable in the physical drill and the Indian Club swing- ing. The varied figures were most interesting The movements of the youths were free and supple and perfectly harmonious. One would think that there was an invisible wire from the skilful instructir, Mr. Donald Munro, to every student. The orders were follow- ed and obeyed with clock work regularity. The first and second prizes consisted of silver and bronze medals with the Cedar of Lebanon, the emblem of the college and seal, on the face, and the inscription of the game for which it is awarded, on the reverse. The third prizes con- sist of ribbons. This year, an American philan- thropist Mr. Ralph Williams presented to the college a beautiful silver cup which curiously enough, after an erratic journey of six months, turned up just on the eve of the field day. On this cup the name of the department winning the majority of the points will be inscribed. What a relic it will be a generation hence!

The distribution of prizes was made from the field by the Honorable G.B. Raundal, the American Consul General. Among the distinguished guest that attended were H E. the Vali of Beyrout, and other high Turkish officials, as well as some of the Consuls; Muzaffer Pasha the Mutessarif of the Lebanon, not having been able to attend for reasons of health was repre- sented by his first Dragoman Abdulla Bey Khouri. One leaves the games, and the college with an inspired feeling of admiration and gratitude. The noblest work done by foreigners in this country is its work, and we wish both the President Emeritus and the present President to whom the college owes so much, the former for his great powers of organization, and the latter for the strenous energy and eloquent enthusiasm by which he had developed and advanced already founded work, we wish them the happiness of enjoying the full fruits of their noble work.

div.head: GYMKHANA AT PORT SAID
(FROM OUR OWN CORRESPONDENT)
div.p: PORT SUDAN, 24 April To spend a pleasant afternoon at Port Sudan is by no means an easy performance, and the committee of the Sports Club, had an excellent idea in organising a gymkhana for last Friday. In spite of a very hot sun, all Port Sudan, irrespective of nationality, and many visitors from Suakim were on the spot, the fair sex, being especially well represented, and the fashionable hats of the ladies made the scene more picturesque, and were a striking contrast to the black faces of the Sudanese, and curly hair og the Hodenhoes. The buffet was well patronised during the intervals, and the band of the 7th Sudanese, playing different selections during the afternoon added to the variety. The events which were many and interesting, were as follows:- Pony Race for ponies of 14 hands and over, to be ridden by members of the club. Course about 6 furlongs. Eight entrues: 1st. Mir. Hawker Bey, Riding Kaffir, 2nd Capt. Draper riding Bahr el Ahmar.
Pony Race, for ponies under 14.1 hands. Open to all comers. No pony to be ridden by a sais. Course as above Five entries: 1st Mr. Sinclair riding Mosquito, 2nd Mr. Pease riding Garden Party.
Donkey Race. Open to all Europeans and Egyptian officers. Course as for ponies. Four- teen entries. 1st M. A. Arif Eff. Lahib, 2nd Capt. Draper.
Camel Race. Open to European and Egyptian officers. Course about two miles. Seven entries. 1st Mr. Devine, 2nd Bimb. Mackintosh.
Pony Race for ponies 14.1 hands and over. Open to all comers. Course as before. Eight entries. 1st Capt. Draper riding the Kaffir, 2nd Mir. Hawker Bey riding the Bahr el Ahmar.

Assinine Pyjama Race. Open members of the club and donkeys. Competitors to ride donkey bare back to a heap of pyjamas, select and put on complete suit and return to winning post. Fourteen entries : 1st Mr. Devine, 2nd Mr. Morris. Rickshaw Race. Open to members of the club. Eight entries : 1st Messrs Levick and Gerrish, 2nd Messrs. Reade and Davies.
Mule Race. Open to members of the club and Egyptian Officers : 1st Mr. Laurie, 2nd M.A. Arif Eff. Labib.

Camel Race for natives. Competitors to mount in a line with spectators tent, rideround a mark back to basin, containing a five piastro piece, buried in flour, pick out the coin with his mouth, ride round the mark again and finish by tent. This race excited keen interest, and the field was roaring with laughter, as the competitors rode back with their faces covered with flour. El Miralai Hawker Bey, Governor of the Province, distributed the prizes, and to the strains of the band playing the British and Khedivial Anthems, the company se- parated and thus ended a very pleasant after- noon. Every praise is due to the committee, and specially to the president of the club, Kaim. Drury Bey, to whose indefatigable efforts is due all the success.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui a midi et demie).

Les affaires quoique pen nombreuses ont porté sur un chiffre relativement important de titres. On'a échangé plus de 900. aétions dela Banque d’Orient qui remonte 4 124 francs 50. Il y ade tres forts acheteurs pour cette valeur qui est encore sous le pair. L’Union fee été également trés demandée, mais les vendeurs font défaut. On a traité principa- lement les Buildings Land,la Banque d’Athé nés, la Cassa di Sconto, la Nile Land, et les Spinning.

La misé aux enchéres d’un certain nombre titres faite a la requéte de la succession P. Glymenopoulo n'a pu avoir lieu a la cor- beille ou les cours de compensation sont de rigueur. On assure que la National Bank of Egypt n’a pas l’intention de procéder pour le mo- ment a la nouvelle émission d’actions qui nécessitera, comme l'on sait un million de livres sterling.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Le Caire; Lundi 29 Avril 1907, Le taux de Vescompte libre 4 Londres a été élevé, vendredi: passé, de 1/8 43 1/4 et est resté Ace prix le lendemain. Au Stock Ex- change, le Consolidé anglais a baisse, samedi, de 1/8 a 85 1/2. L'Unifiée s’est maintenue a 102 1/4, La National Bank a rétrogradé de 1/4 vendredi a 23 1/2 et est restée invariée a ce cours le jour suivant. L'Agricole a perdu 1,8 vendredi a 8 1/2, mais l’a rattrapé samedi a 8*5/8, La Daira est demeurée inchangée a 15 3/8, de méme que la Delta Light a 10 1/2. A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien a ré- trogradé de 1 frane 4 724 et la Banque d’A- thénes de 1 franc également a 123

Ici, le marché des valeurs reste dans la si- tuation exceptionnelle déterminée par les cours de compensation établis le 22 Avril courant, Ce matin, le nombre des transactions prati- quées aux prix qui contituent la cote est réduit a dix-sept.

Ainsi que nous l’avons déja dit,:cet état de chosessemitintiendra nécessairement jusqu aprés la liquidation d’Alexandrie (qui se terminera fe 10 Mai prochain) en vertu de l'accord in- tervenu entre les deux places.

En attendant, par suite des dispositions prises avant-hier par les comités dest deux Bourses, tout porte a croire que lés réglements de fin courant sont appelés a etre faits sans encombre. Un autre point rassurant, c'est que, grace a la solidarité qui régne actuellement on n’appréhende plus que des Agences soient mises dans la pénible obligation de susperidre leurs paiements. Il y a lieu de noter, en Outre, que la meilleure tenue du coton pourrait, si elle se maintenait; contribuer largement a ren- dre la position générale moins génante, voire a armener une prompte amélioration.

L’assemblée générale ordinaire de la Société Anonyme Agricole et Industrielle d’Egypte a été tenue, joudi passé, au siége social au Caire, Les comptes et bilan de l’exercice clos le 31 Janvier, 1907 ont été approuvéset il a été décidé de repartir un dividende de Frs, 55 aux actions de capital et Frs. 60 aux parts de dividende, payables & partir du ler Mai prochain, aut guichets de la Société.
Les actionnaires de la George Nungovich Hotels Co.sont convoqués en assemblée générale ordinaire pour le 22 Mai prochain, 4 4 h, p.m., au siege social au Caire, Grand Continental Hotel.

A l'ordre du jour: rapport du conseil d’ad ministration ; approbation des comptes de lexercice 1906-1907 ; fixation du dividende ; nomination.d’un administrateur en remplace- ment de M, George Royle, sortant et réeli- gible.
Le dépot des titres doit etre effectué au plus tard le 17 Mai.
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

Les actionnaires de Egyptian Land Investment and Building Co, sont informés que le troisiéme appel de 5 shellings par action est payable le 2 Mai prochain aux guichets de la Banque d’Athénes a Alexandrie ou au Caire. Toute somme non payée au 5 Mai portera in- térét, au taux de 9 % l'an, a partir du 2 Mai 1907.

TELEGRAMS.
GERMAN SUSPICIONS.
FEARS OF ISOLATION. LONDON, April 29.

Articles in German newspapers and speeches and interviews of German politicians during the last few days emphasize the continued suspicion, even irritation, with which the sup posed endeavours of Great Britain to hem in Germany fiave been viewed in German political circles, At the same time a Paris paper has been prominently publishing interviews with leading Germans,in favour of friendly relations with France. (Reuter)
THE DUMA’S FATE. ——o——— RAISING OF RECRUITS.

ST. PETERSBURG, April 30. The fate of the Duma hangs upon the result of the debate on the War Minister's proposal to raise 459,000 recruits. The members yes- terday resented the hectoring tone of the War Minister who insisted that it was neces sary to maintain the prestige, of the nation after the Japanese war. He declared that the project would be carried, out even if the Duma disapproved. The sitting was adjourned owing to the uproar which ensued. (Reuter)
ST. PETERSBURG, April 29. The Duma is secretly discussing the contin- gent of the army. Violent speeches were deli- vered and the meeting broke up in a tumult (Havas)
THE PARIS STRIKES.

TRADES UNION LEADERS ARRESTED. PARIS, April 29, Owing to violent speeches in connection with the café waiters and provision dealers strikes, the secretary of the Provision Trades Union and two members of the Confederation of Labour have been arrested. Strong measures are being adopted for the maintenance of order on May-Day. The garrison is being heavily reinforced. (Reuter) PARIS, April 29. Measures have been taken in view of the 1st of May. The ringleaders have been arrested. (Havas)

MORE DREADNOUGHTS. LONDON, April 29. Orders for sixty 12-inch guns have been placed at Woolwich, Armstrong’s, and Messrs, Vickers Maxim for three British and three Brazilian Dreadnoughts at present in course of construction. (Reuter)
FRENCH ABYSSINIAN MINISTER. PARIS, April 29.

Ex-Deputy M. Deville has been appointed French Minister in Abyssinia and will assume the post return of M. Klobukowski (Reuter ) PARIS, April 29. M. Gabriel Deville replaces M. Lagarde at Addis Abeba. He will join his post on the return of M. Klobukowski. (Havas)
REVOLUTIONARY RUSSIAN TROOPS.
ST. PETERSBURG, April 29, It is stated that the revolutionary propa- ganda amongst the troops has seriously increas- ed. Many arrests have been made here and at Warsaw. (Reuter)
BOMBS IN ODESSA. ODESSA, April 29. Sixteen bomhs have been discovered in the villa of General Kaulbars, the Governor Gene- ral, which was taken for the summer.( Reuter)

TELEGRAMS. RESIGNATION OF CONSERVATIVE M.P. London, April 29. Sir W. E. Evans Gordon, M.P., has resigned owing to his wife’s health. ( Reuter) Major Sir William Eden Evans Gordon: who was created a knight in 1906, has been Member of Parliament since 1900, representing the Stepney Division, Tower Hamlets, in the interests of the Conservative party. Lady Gor- don ig the widow of the ninth Marquis of Tweedale, and married Sir William in 1892. Sir William joined the Indian Staff Corps from Sandhurst at the age of nineteen, became major in 1896 and retired the following year. KING LEOPOLD IN PARIS. Paris, April 29. King Leopold visited the President of the Republic and M.M. Clemenceau and Pichon. (Havas) THE MONTAGNINI PAPERS PARIS, April 29. A décree recalls M Lemarchand, who is compromised by the cements of Monseigneur Montagnini (Havas) GREECE AND ROUMANIA. Vienna, April 29. It is rumoured that negotiations are going on ta settle the Greco-Roumanian trouble. (Havas) THE SUDAN, OLD AND NEW. With complete fitness Dr. Wallis Budge dedicates these splendid volumes to Sir Wil- liam Edmund Garstin, who, as he biblically puts it, “has measured and curbed the River of Egypt, and set bounds to the flood thereof, and turned the Wilderness into a pool of water and the parched places into water Springs, and made the Desert to blossom as the rose.” This work, which really deserves to be_ styled monu- metital, says the “Morning Post,” is the result. of investigations made by the author daring the pkst decade in the course of four archwo logigal missions to the Sudan. Dr, Wallis Budge was sent out first in 1897 by the Trus- tees of the British Museum, by arrangement with the Sirdar, then Sir Herbert Kitchener. He went out again in the winter of 1898-99 ; and inthe spring of 1902 made a third jour- ney, this time under the direction of Sir Regi- nald Wingate, who had succeeded Lord Kit- ¢hener in the Sirdarship. Finally, in the spring of 1905: the author was sent to the Sudan to assist Sir Reginald in collecting antiquities for the newly-established Museum at Khartoum, in company with Mr. J. W. Crowfoot, Inspector of Education. This last visit was particularly rich in discoveries, which are fully described in the first of the two volumes. This part of the work contains a narrative of the results of the four missions and a description of the temples, pyramids, and other monuments which Dr. Wallis Budge was privileged to examine and, in some cases, partly to excavate. Of special interest, as leading up to his own investiga- tions, is the summary of the “splendid archaeo- logical work” done in the Sudan by travellers of various nationalities during recent years, particularly by Cailliault, Hoskins, and Lepsius. History rather than archaeology forms the basis of the second volume. The author begins his fascinating narrative with great raid into the district made by Seneferu, an Egyptian King about B C. 3766, and ends it with a summary of chief events which happened there in the Year of Grace 1904. It would seem that Christianity penetrated the Sudan by way or Egypt in the early centuries of our era. Indeed, we are told that in the Sixth Century it had permeated the minds of the Nubians so thor- oughly that a native King succeeded in establishing a Christian kingdom in Northern *The Egyptian Sudan: Its History and Monuments. By Dr E.A. Wallis Budge, Keeper of the Egyptian and Assyrian Antiquities in the British Museum. Two Volumes, Kegan Paul, Trench, Trubner, and Co. Limited), 2gs. net. Sudan, with Dongola as his capital. That king- dom flourished for about seven hundred years, and proved an effective barrier to the advance of Islam. Facts for history of the Sudan from the Seventh Century to the end of the Fifteenth are few, but they suffice to enable the author to put together a fairly connected narrative. He says : It is clear that the Northern Sudan was subject to the Khalifas and their representa- tives,in Egypt, and that its ralers were com- pelled by them to pay the “Bakt,” or annual tribute of slaves It is equally clear, however, that the native Christian Church made a persistent and gallant stand against Islam, and that Christianity flourished in the country from the First Cataract to Soba on the Blue Nile. The testimony of Mohammedan writers proves that there were hundreds of churches in the country between these limits, and we know from other sources that many of them were fine buildings, the walls. of which were decorated with painted figures of Saints, &c. The form of belief which the Sudan Christians professed was that of Alexandria, i.e., Jacobite and the Liturgy was recited in Greek, and we may assume, that the chief members of the clergy came from the Mother Church in Alexandria. About the Thirteenth Century Christianity began to decline, the elergy lost their hold on the people, who either voluntarily or under compulsion—for Islam was in the ascendant— became followers of the Prophet. In the early years of the Sixteenth Century Islam had triumphed, and, from that date to the present time the population of the whole Sudan has consisted practically of Mohammedans and Pagans, As Dr Wallis Budge points out, it is impossible, with the facts at present available, to write a connected history of the country between 1520 and 1820, but we know that the Sultans and tribal Sheikhs waged war with each other in true Sudani fashion, the object on either side being to capture as many slaves and women and as much gold as possible, and to destroy the enemy and his country. The méthods employed were always the same, and seem to be inherent in the race. It will interest many people to learn that the little Arabic MS. in the British Museum, numbered “Oriental 2345,” belonged to Gener- al Gordon, and was presented by him to the National Collection in 1881. It contains, says Dr. Wallis Budge, an excellent, though brief, summary of the history of the Sudan from 1504 to 1871, and his opinion—which, of course, suffices—is “worth editing and trans- lating.” Coming to a date so recent as 1897, the author draws a vivid picture of “the state of misery to which the country had been brought within a space of fifty years by the misrule of its former masters,” and then compares it with the extraordinarily improved state of things existing to-day, thanks to Lord Kitchener, Lord Cromer, Sir Reginald Wingate, and Sir William Garstin, to name only the chief among the brave, devoted, and able administrators of various , degrees by whom the wonderful work of regeneration has been brought about. Putting lightly aside the “sentimental philo- Egyptians who criticise and find fault with details in the administration of the Sudan by a Government which is only a few years old,” the author pays a fine tribute to Lord Cromer and his coadjutors. “None but an autocrat, who was at the same time patient, wise, and strong, could do what Lord Cromer has done there.” In this necessarily brief and inadequate notice reference has been made chiefly to the historical side of Dr. Wallis Budge’s great work ; but the archeologist and the anthropo- logist will find it brimful of interest and instruction, set forth in clear and anthoritative fashion. Farther, it is abundantly illustrated with excellent photographs, maps, and plans. LEGION OF FRONTIERSMEN. We received recently a visit from a mem ber of the Legion of Frontiersmen, who is making a tour through various parts of the Empire, with the object, interalia, of making the Legion more widely known. Among the Englishmen who have lived on the outskirts of civilization, or beyond its limits, there exists the finest possible material for a fighting force which any country might be proud to own or fear to face. The time-expired soldier, trained and hardened by years of campaigning, with experience of inestimable value in war, but un- able to re-enlist in the regular forces; the colonial whose life has been spent in learning the great game of keeping alive when circum- stances—or men—oppose all possible obstacles to living ; the engineer, man of infinite re- source, the sailor, likewise trained in a hard school that makes men ; these men, who do not eare, or are not able, to join the regular forces, would most of them be just as keen on taking part in the next war as they were in our last little aftair in the south of the continent. And it is the object uf the Legion of Frontiersmen to find out and enroll such men in time of peace, so that when next there is a call to arms it may be possible to offer to the Empire a force of picked men able and willing to go anywhere and do anything, The headquarters of the Legion is in London and any interest- ed—we hope there may be many—can obtain all information from the Secretary at 6 Adam Street, Adelphi CARLTON HOTEL BULKELEY (near Alexandria) half way to San Stefano RAMLEH’S FASHIONABLE HOTEL. CATHOLIC SEAMEN’S CLUB.

In presenting their fifth annual report the Committee of the Catholic Seaman’s Club, Port Said, record that they have not received from the public the same assistance during the past year asin the previous ones. Had it not been for fhe most rigid economy and the com- paratively heavy balance in hand on 1st January 1906 the committee would have had to present a still more unfavorable balance sheet. The club was fairly well attended during the year under review and the committee record with pleasure such remarks as the fol- lowing which appear in the visitor's book “The only place where an Englisman can have a quiet rea?” “A very nice place for aman down in his luck” as signs that the club is doing the work it isintended to do. During the past year the committee sustained a great loss with death of the Lady Amabele Kerr, Treasurer of the Catholic Truth Society (Seamen’s Branch) who was a strong supporter of the club and had ever since its opening evinced the greatest interest in the same, Messrs. Geo, Newnes Ld. have continued sending contribu- tions of literature during the year and the committee also acknowledge with thanks the receipt of a parcel of reading matter in June last from the Amalgamated Press, These contributions are very welcome and the com- mittee would be grateful if others followed these examples. The committee regret they are obliged to close the year’s accounts with only a small balance of Frs. 17,75 in hand and with two months rent—November and Decem- ber—and the caretaker’s wages for December to pay. The committee again beg to remind the public that the club is in nowise sectarian in its work. It was opened, as expressed in the front page of this report, with the object of providing a place of recreation and resort for the many seamen who visit this port and who have no other place to go to, except low drink- ing shops. The committee trust the general public and especially those connected with shipping will give their support to the club in 1907, otherwise the committee will be com- pelled to abandon the work, which it is need- less to say they would do very reluctantly.
SPORT AND PLAY. ——— CRICKET. RAILWAY INSTITUTE versus ARMY ORDNANCE CORPS.

The match took place last Friday on the Institute ground. The Countess Cromer, Mr. F. H. Trevithick and G. Bain Bey were present and the beautiful large verandah was full to overflowing. The Ordnance skipper won the toss and elected to bat first. McGuire and Willes went to the wickets but soon after double figures had been reached the latter ran himself ont. Deighton stayed in while a few were put on but four wickets liad fallen when the score was 42, Windsor, who was bowling splendidly having obtained all four. Parrington and Smith then made a splendid stand, both hitting very hard. When the 100 had been hoisted they were still partners but soon after Walker caught Parrington in the slips ; Smith continued in but when 142 he was caught. Windsor and Revd. Burns batted first for the Institute and when a long partnership between the two seemed probable Windsor was clean bowled. Revd J. T. Burns played in splendid style for, going in first he was unbeaten at the finish with 56 to his credit. He was not in trouble with the bowling once during his long innings. Riley helped him to put on 35 for the fifth wicket. Stumps were drawn at 6 p.m. the Institute having: obtained 112 for six wickets so an extremely interesting match ended in a draw. AVIS AUX ACTIONNAIRES.

L'Assembléo, Géoérele Extraordinaire qui avaiete convequée poarle 20 Avril n’ayant pas réuvi le nombre d’actions voulu, Messiears les Actionnaires de la National Bank sont con voqués a nouvesa en Assemb'és Géuéral: Extraordinaire poir le Mercredi 8 Mai 1907 a cinq heures de l’aprés midi, au siege social, au Caire:
Dans cette seconde réunion les délitérations reront valablement priser, quel que soit 'e nom- bre des actions représentées.

Augmentation da Capital Social et modi- fication de l'article 10 des statute. |

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie
AVIS
div.p: Il est porte a la conaissance du public que conformement aux avis paru dans les Journaux, tout candidat au poste d'Ingenieur ou Dessinateur devra joindre a sa demande : 1) Un certificat de naissance ou tout docu- ment en tenant lieu 2) Un certificat de bonne conduite 3) Tout certificat ou documents etablissant son aptitude Toute demande non accompagnee de ces pieces ne sera pas prise en consideration lors du concours. Alexandrie le 23 Avril 1907. L'Administrateur 30117-3-2 (signe) W.P. CHATAWAY

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat Egyptian
AVIS
div.p: L'administration des chemins de fer et Telegraphes de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter a la connaissance du public qu'a partir du ler Mai prochain, un bureau telegraphique sera ouvert a Nakhl (Sinai), pour l'echange des depeches en langues Europeennes et Arabe.

Le tarif des telegrammes a destination de Nakhl sera le meme que celui des telegrammes a destination de Tor, C'est-a-dire le double de la taxe ordinaire appliquee aux telegrammes pour l'interieur. Le Caire, le 23 Avril 1907. 30105-2-2
AVIS

L'Administration des Chemins des fer et Telegraphes de l'Etat a l'honneur de porter a la connaissance du public que le bureau telegraphiques de Sennouris sers ouvert pour l'echange des telegrammes en langues Euro- piennes a partir du ler Mai 1907 Le Caire, le 26 Avril 1907. 30140-2-2

div.head: Sudan Government
NOTICE
div.p: Persons importing Egyptian Labourers to work in the Sudan are reccomended to enter into a written contract with them. This contract should be explained and signed by the Labouryers in presence of an official or other reliable witness. 28283A-30-10-907

div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier
DE L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
div.p: Le Supplement Commercial et Financier de L'"Egyptian Gazette" parsit chaque Samedi a midi de facon a pouvoir etre expedie par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des revues completes et impartiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marche des valeurs ; les der- nieres statistiques jusqu'a la vielle de sa publi- cation: des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des depaches officielles envoyees a la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc. etc. L'abonne pour une annee en Egypte coute 1 L.E. compris les frais de poste ; pour l'etranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.
